comments.commentBody:
@Bruce Johnson
You are unilaterally redefining "invading". Crimea and Donbass are within the internationally-recognized borders of Ukraine. Russian troops seized control of one and entered the other, that is an invasion. The fact that they weren't always Ukrainian is a non-excuse which could be used to unilaterally redraw many borders.

Further, there is no basis for believing that NATO was looking to base in Sevastopol or that Ukraine was looking to violate the basing agreement that allows the Russians there.
Read at least wiki. What you are telling is not true

On the TV show Fraser they lived in a high rise, and a large telescope, apparently not for astronomical use, sat right in the middle of the living room.  I remembered that, because I've always been interested in astronomy.
Professional athletes, OK. Models, sure. Even personal trainers are OK. But a senator, any senator? Seriously? The woman really had some weird obsession.
Most of these bath tubs in many of the apartments will remain hardly, if ever, used at all by the absentee owners. $igh.
In Manhattan, "above the tree line" is ideal real estate.   Lower floors are subject to street noise.  And believe me, it is noisy.

The one with a wood vanity is the best - it adds a warmth and beauty.
As for the views, I prefer looking out at my japanese maples

@Yuliy
Popular enough that the government that it brought into power has one a presidential and a parliamentary election. The protests stopped being peaceful in self-defense, Yanukovich initiated the violence.

"To “qualify” for being a coup, it does not have to involve military force, although, historically"
Yes, it does.

I did not miss that - it just not the point of the article.

The point of the article is that these people are WHINING that "ohmigawd we have to lose our jobs just like everyone else."

But to address that point -so what? They were not trained as completely as the officers who went through the academies. Of course they will be the first to go - the 2nd and 3rd string picks usually are.

Destroy away, oh, fearless warrior. I am sure Putin will have no objection to you hopping on the next plane to Kiev. Used Kalashnikovs can be had for 700 bucks in the streets there. I am also sure you will make a much more competent "destroyer of invaders" than the Ukrainian conscript deserter who will sell it to you.

My ex-husband was caught in the RIF after Vietnam. It was a quantitative reduction and not a qualitative one which means it was just picking names to lower the number of, mainly Captains, in the Army.

We didn't get a big payout and he never received a penny in pension. He had served eight years at the time.

I wonder how in the world these people are getting a 1/3 pension for less than eight years? I didn't think there was any pension unless the soldiers served a full twenty years, or more.

These people are getting a very good deal, with a partial pension and a large cash payout. It certainly would have been a lot easier on us if we had gotten that when my ex-husband was separated.

It does seem like the current soldiers are getting very special treatment that wasn't given to soldiers in the past.

By the way, my ex-husband was also a volunteer.

How do you suggest we "advance plan" for cancer?  Or a car accident?   Or job loss with loss of health insurance, and long-term employment due to economy, age and other discrimination?   Even if you're lucky enough to have stayed employed at a rate where you can save, it doesn't take more than one hospitalization to eat up that year of living expenses that you saved.   At any rate, the article is really not so much about what some seem to see as the lack of character of people that have been forced into debt -- it's about corporations knowingly and blatantly breaking the law to collect on debts that the consumer no longer owes -- and walking free.  Where does THEIR high character come into play?

Mary Kay Klassen, I'll bet you would feel very much at home in a country such as Bangladesh, Pakistan or India where the debt bondage is never forgiven and a child can be born into an ancestor's debt bondage.  Thousands, if not millions, of children must labor twelve hours a day and cannot go to school because someone in their poor family incurred debt before they were even born that is impossible to pay back completely.

Mary Kay... Thanks goodness we are governed by laws rather than judgmental, merciless personalities such as yours. Were the latter the case, I hate to think of the fate of the "ne'er-do-well" woman diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer who falls behind on her credits cards (on your watch). This "toddler" should never have become sick.  I hate to think of all those "toddlers" who were laid off during the Great Recession and have been jobless ever since.  Certain people would not be satisfied until these "toddlers" are buried in a popper's grave or laid in a pine wood box.  Then, we could exact their debts upon the heads of their children. What a bleak picture of society you paint. ...So 400 years ago!

How one handles their finances and credit cards shows the personal ability of an individual to be responsible, committed in the long run, and take responsibility for their choices and not make society pay, the banks pay, or the credit card companies pay who have already paid the businesses who services or products the individual purchased.  In my opinion, there should never be bankruptcy for individuals or business, but an easing of all interest on the debt, but payments made on the debt each month, year after year until it all paid off, or when one dies, collecting the debt from the estate.  The idea that somehow people should be allowed to behave like toddlers is ridiculous!

Anything with a mass has gravity. You have gravity. If all human beings congregated on the north pole and leaped simultaneously we would pull the earth up.

Big and small....all things with matter exert force, even our sun wobbles slightly from the gravitational affect of the Planet Jupiter.

The Mathematics, calculations, electronics, Astronomy, Blood, sweat and tears involved in achieving this amazing, mind boggling feat with such precision is a testament to the super level of human scientific capability and the combined efforts of brilliant minds working in harmony.
My humble and sincere congratulations to all the scientists and engineers of this successful project.

keep in mind that you are moving ,  you are on the spinning and orbiting earth, which is moving faster than a bullet.  So when you throw that ball you do so while moving at a speed greater than 750 MPH.

Ukraine is not a NATO member state, so there has been no aggression against NATO. Security alliances are not obligated to defend non-members.

There is no excuse for Putin's behavior, but there is a powerful argument that NATO and EU expansion contributed to the current situation in the first place. Remember that it was not that many years ago that NATO formally talked about offering membership to Ukraine.

Without condoning Russian behavior, we should not be shocked that Russia would oppose a western leaning Ukraine on its border. How would we respond to a pro-Chinese or pro-Russian Canada or Mexico on ours? How would did we respond to a pro-Soviet Cuba? The Bay of Pigs was naked aggression as well, even if you think it was for a good cause against a bad regime.

The US has long held the Monroe Doctrine. Why are we shocked that Russia has a Monroe Doctrine of its own? Again, none of this “morally” justifies Russia action, but it does suggest that state interests and realist security and power dominate international politics, just as they always have.

Note to the new Republican Congress.... Prove that you are not anti-science by funding the James Webb Telescope.

http://space.about.com/od/telescopesandoptics/a/Should-Nasa-Build-The-Ja...

Opinion polls? Is this some kind of joke? There were two referenda and two general elections in both Donetsk and Lugansk, in which people of Donbass clearly expressed their will. And it was not to be ruled by an illegal fascist junta in Kiev.

I wonder if cutting through the glass is as easy as hollywood movies. The assassin from Skyfall did it like he was eating breakfast. I guess it would be harder. Great job NYFD! Always grateful for your service!
Umm yeah, the USSR did exist during World War II... and a substantial percentage of the Soviet war dead were Ukrainians.

"the incredible runup in the national debt by Obama'.....You can pretend your Obama deficit story is true all you want, but here are the facts. Obama inherited a budget deficit of $1350 billion dollars from the Bush Administration. In 6 years that deficit has been reduced to $483 billion dollars, which based on the economy is lower than the average for a deficit over the last 40 years. The deficit reduction by the Obama Administration represents an historic achievement by any  Presidential Administration ever.

@Bruce Johnson
"That the Soviets attached Donbass to the Ukrainian SSR in the 1920's does not, in fact, mean that the region is actually Ukrainian"
It actually does. This is a border that was recognized by the Soviet Union until its demise and then recognized as an international border globally, including by Russia (in the Budapest Memorandum). That's what made those internal borders international ones that demarcated an independent Ukraine. By your logic, Russia can legitimately go into any former USSR "republic" and annex territory. There is no principle of international law that such a sentiment squares with. That's the relevant perspective.

"then the Ukrainian SSR's boundaries would have encapsulated the country's current western, central, and northern regions, and nothing more."
That is conclusory and unsubstantiated.

It's also Ukrainian by virtue of a majority of the population being Ukrainian.

"The legitimacy of Ukraine governing Donbass is highly questionable."
Not even remotely. The Ukraine has every right to have its military suppress a rebellion there, every right whatsoever. It's the Russians who have no right whatsoever to be there.

What most people do not understand, is it is the clerks for each justice that does the research, and gives the justice he or she works for, the rational for their decisions.

So a clerk for Thomas, will work to find any and all previous decisions that will fit his political philosophy, that is why the justice gave him the job. Most people do not read the decision and do not have time to read the Reporters for the other courts that lead up to the decision.

Even though a justice may dislike a particular law, he/she has to justify a decision. As we see, Ms, Greenhouse cites previous decisions, to show what has gone on before. Looking over some of them, I believe Thomas will be rated as one of the poorest in the courts history.

Scalia will not be judged very well either, but it takes many years to reverse these rulings.
FDR was able to get the court to refuse to hear some cases regarding some of his actions by proposing a constitutional change to the court, it was called "Packing The Court." But he had the backing of the public who were unhappy with some rulings.

It will take a few more appointments to reverse some of the current decisions, but as long as the GOP can block new appointees, we are stuck with them. So again, put the blame where it belongs, on the people who put those in power that gave us this court.

R. Law,
Even a GOP majority on the Hill and in the White House must STILL answer to the Court no matter if the bench was fill of Karl Rove clones. Remember, GOPers feature diversity of opinions, as with Tea Partiers versus the old go-alongs.

While the 4 aging liberals on the Court have to abide by the old socialist ideal, the others are free to do The Right Thing.

Anyone thinking GOPers named to the Court remain conservative has no clue how Earl Warren or the first woman named to the Court evolved.

>

Could not disagree with you about the Court's power. True they do not have an enforcement branch that they control, but assuming the rulings they pass are upheld by DOJ, the States.... they have all the enforcement they require.

For example if they overturn Roe, sure everybody (DOJ, POTUS, Senate the House....) could ignore that ruling, but that is not going to happen. The "rule of law" would be out the window. I'm unsure of your point here.

The Chief Justice "expressed concern that the “partisan rancor” of Washington could spill over onto the court."

Too late.

The issue now is to repair that damage enough to save the Court.

The Court's only power is the deference to it by the other two branches and the public. Without that, it has no means to enforce its opinons, no power at all.

Past misconduct by the Court and by serveral of the justices in intemperate partisan public addresses have done serious damage to that deference.

The Court is now on the ragged edge of self destruction. Witness this reporters "I surrender."

Justice Roberts better be thinking of damage control. Otherwise, soon enough, nobody will much care about his Court's opinions. They'll just be over ridden by some Executive Order of a Congressional Act done without hesitation, in ways nobody would have considered before.

The Court never before took its powers for granted. It was always careful about that. Now it has grown reckless.
Estonia or Finland? Certainly not. Poland? Definitely not. Germany? Probably not, but will have to evaluate when it comes to it. England, France, Canada, US? Who would want them anyhow?

Actually, in the case of Wellesley, the annual cost of operating the College comes to just under $90,000 per student.  Note that financial aid is not an expense, and so is NOT included in this number.  You may well question why this cost is so high.  But it is not accurate to say that it is so high because full pay students and their families are paying (some of) the cost of the students on financial aid.  Even full pays (~ paying $60k a year) are receiving a subsidy of approximately $30,000 per year off the actual cost of their education, which is not that much smaller than the average grant for students receiving financial aid (~$37,000).

True the media could easily demonstrate the rampant corruption, but alas, the plutocrats own all of the media so their only interest is highlighting the gridlock so the masses learn not to expect any acton, because the rich already have everything just where they want it; and the indentured servants are to be kept quiet and dumbed down, until they all quit voting and a handful of angry greedy old white men, the scariest people on the planet, make the decision amongst themselves like the last chance Monopoly game.

If I was pitching a documentary to a network head it would focus on following various politicians doing fund raising activities while they sell out the American public. It would be entitled "Trolling for Dollars" (Your U.S. Congressman at Work).  The possibilities would be endless.  How cool would it be to tag along with Republican Presidential candidates as they make the pilgrimage to Las Vegas to "Schmooze with Sheldon" and bargain their Mid East positions for cold hard cash.  Some industrious newsman could get a camera and microphone in the room where the meetings take place ala the 47% tape.  Now that would make some riveting and informative T.V.
